course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Plant Biology
course.description: Structure and life processes in plants; cellular structures; molecular and cellar mechanism; transport of water and nutrients; nutrition and soil; reproduction; photosynthesis; growth and development; biotechnology.
course.prerequisites: LIFS 2040 OR LIFS 2210

reviews.author: Leon2002
reviews.title: Attend lectures and especially the tutorials
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm
Li’s part
1. Agriculture, food and human
2. Plant cellular structure and chemical composition
3. Plant cellular structure and chemical composition

Leung’s part
4. Plant classification
5. Shoot & root primary growth
6. Photosynthesis
7. Respiration & Energy
8. Movement of Water and Solutes
9 Plant defense responses to pathogens

Final exam
Li’s part
1. Introduction to flowering plants
2. Reproduction of plant and development of seeds
3. Hormonal physiology: Auxin, Cytokinin, Ethylene, Gibberellin, ABA, etc.  
4. Plant response to environmental stimuli : phototropism, thigmotropism, nastic movement, etc.
5. Plant cell signalling
6. Plant molecular biotechnology

Comment: A comprehensive introduction to the field of plant biology. Learned a lot about plants in general— from the smallest cells, chemicals to plant species and their organs’ interaction with the environment.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Li uses analogies to explain concepts and sometimes go beyond the lecture PowerPoint to share some additional knowledge.

Leung reads the PowerPoint and the lectures are a bit boring but she explains the difference in Calvin Cycle of each types of plants well.

Nonetheless, there is a tutorial session after every 2 lectures. These sessions allow you to ask question. This is beneficial to students who wants direct and quick answers when they miss and don’t understand some parts in the previous lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
50% midterm exam
50% final exam
My scores: Midterm(27/40), Final(71/100)
Got a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
0 assignments/presentations
Takes effort to revise the lecture contents.
Both exams are closed book so thorough understanding and memorisation of the concepts are required.

reviews.author: vincentchy
reviews.title: LIFS 2080
reviews.comment_content: Content is quite easy to understand which include basic knowledge about plant like nutrition, photosynthesis , cell structure ,plant hormones,transport of water, growth and development; biotechnology.

reviews.comment_workload: Only mid-term and final exam. Question is quite easy. Some question require a well understanding to the concept, thus revision is recommended.

reviews.author: Chrissie
reviews.title: plant biology
reviews.comment_content:
First part was about plant growth, plant structure...
The second part was about plant hormones and plant movement. There were 6 plant hormones in total and 2 major plant movement.
reviews.comment_teaching: Both professors are nice. They explained the course content very well. They would give a lot of additional information in class, and sometimes the content of ppt are wrong, they would tell you in class, so you better attend lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
The midterm exam wasn't hard, just mc questions.
The final exam had few long questions.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework. No group project. No quiz. Only midterm and final.

reviews.author: NM
reviews.comment_content:
The content is about plant structure, growth, reproduction, photosynthesis, respiration... before the midterm.
The final is mainly about plant hormones and the interaction between them.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lectures are interesting. They are nice and are familiar with the course content, they can explain the concepts clearly.
However, the notes provided are neat, just not self-explanatory as you might expected, attending the lectures and jotting down some extra notes are really needed. (and no lecture videos are provided)
reviews.comment_grading:
50% midterm and 50% final exam
the grading is fairly good, the mean grade is B and most people got B range
reviews.comment_workload:
Only midterm (all MC) and final exam (MC+a few short question), which are simple and short.
But you need to attend the lectures to get a good grade, although no attendance is taken.
You will know what to be examined during the lecture, so that you don't have to memorize unnecessary things.

reviews.author: kentanggoreng
reviews.comment_content: The course is basically evil; it is easy on the first half as you talk about basic capillary movemnts, photosynthesis, calvin cycle, and other stuff you know in highschool. After midterm, came biochemistry and molecular biology which will surely make to regret taking this course in the first place.
reviews.comment_teaching: Leung (Melody) was quite nice. She was organised and structured. Her English is not the best, but she tries to be friendly, engaging and helpful to her students. Li Ning was the opposite; he was mad insane. Definitely a mess, he handles the biochemistry an dmolecular biology part of the course and yet he fails miserably most of the time to explain concepts to the students. His presentation was also a sloppy mess and hard to understand.
reviews.comment_workload: Just spend your time trying to understand (and memorise) what's provided to you on the lecture notes. Borrowing books from the library also helped a lot to understand the heavy, difficult second part of the course.

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: Bad and harsh Grading
reviews.comment_content:
Li Ning's part
1. Agriculture, food, and human
2. Plant cellular structure and chemical composition
3. Plant cellular structure and chemical composition

Melody's Part
Leung’s part
4. Plant classification
5. Shoot & root primary growth
6. Photosynthesis
7. Respiration & Energy
8. Movement of Water and Solutes
9 Plant defense responses to pathogens
(Midterm exam includes up to here)
Non-cumulative

Li’s part
1. Introduction to flowering plants(None of the MCQ from final exam test on this topic)
2. Reproduction of plant and development of seeds
3. Hormonal physiology: Auxin(IAA,2,6-Ade), Cytokinin, Ethylene, Gibberellin, ABA, etc.  
4. Plant response to environmental stimuli: phototropism, thigmotropism, nastic movement, etc.
5. Plant cell signaling
6. Plant molecular biotechnology( Not examined in Final Exam)
Final Exam includes all Li's part after midterm
reviews.comment_teaching:
Melody's teaching was fine. I can see her enthusiasm for teaching and explaining concepts during lectures. For her review lecture before midterm, Melody will send a typed summary pdf file for those who had attended the lecture in zoom. For those who missed that lecture, they couldn't get that file. So, I recommend not skipping Melody's review lecture before the midterm. That file was quite useful, it summarises all important concepts that we need to remember in preparation for the midterm exam.

But Li Ning's teaching is not good. He even forgot to hold the review lecture before the midterm and had to re-arrange another time slot for us to join. Also, his review lecture only answers your questions. If you don't have any questions to ask him, you can skip it.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is normal to harsh range if you aim for A+. Only a handful(less than 6%) A+ given, which is a harsher grading policy compared to LIFS2220.

My Score:

Midterm(50%): 36/40
Mean:27.1  Highest 38 Lowest: 9

Final(50%): 86/100
Mean: 64.1 Highest: 92 Lowest: 29

Letter Grade: A

Midterm consists of 40 MCQ (50 Mins time limit)
Final exam was made up of 70 MCQ and 2 essay questions( 180 mins time limits)

Midterm and Final both account for 50%.
Do better in midterm to get an edge over the others to secure a better grade. Final exam MCQ are more conceptual and harder than those appeared in midterm for Li Ning's part. Melody's part in midterm was fine

Question to be asked in exams:
What crops are those 6 major crops that provide 80% of total calories to humans?
What examples are the physical defenses in plants?
Folke Skoog discovered which chemicals that stimulate cell division in tobacco plants?
What will be the effect of cytokinin when applied to the aerial part of the plant?
What pairs of hormones are antagonistic against each other in auxiliary bud growth?
Natural occurring IAA was isolated by who?
reviews.comment_workload:
Light to moderate, depends on what grade you aim for
Only midterm and Final
Need to put more effort in Li Ning's part for the Final exam

reviews.author: lhtam
reviews.comment_content:
Before mid-term:
Agriculture, food and human - Li
Plant cellular structure and chemical composition - Li
Shoot & root primary growth - Melody
Shoot & root secondary growth - Melody
Photosynthesis - Melody
Introduction to flowering plants - Li
Reproduction of plant and development of seeds - Li
Hormonal physiology (Auxin) - Li
Hormonal physiology (Ethylene) - Li

After mid-term:
Hormone physiology (Gibberellin) - Li
Hormone physiology (Cytokinin) - Li
Hormone physiology (Abscisic Acid) - Li
Hormone physiology (Brassinosteroids) - Li
Hormone physiology (Salicylic Acid) - Li
Plant response to environment stimuli - Li
Respiration & Energy - Melody
Movement of Water and Solutes - Melody
Plant defense responses to pathogens - Melody
Plant Cell Signaling - Li
Plant molecular biotechnology - Li

There are tutorial sessions after finishing each chapter, as well as before mid-term and final exam.

Content before mid-term is easy as most of them covered in high school already. However, content after mid-term will become difficult as you have to remember the interaction between different hormones which may makes you confused.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Li explains everything clearly with lots of analogy. He will talk about the important concepts which mostly appear in the exam so better come to his class.

Melody is a funny instructor and she will relate daily life examples in the tutorial sessions. However she speaks quite fast so make sure you keep jot down notes during lecture which benefits your understanding.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term consist of 50 MCQs only.
Mean: 30/50 SD: 6

Final exam consist of 40-ish MCQs and 3 short essays questions.
Marks are not disclosed.

Make sure you understand the concepts but not just reciting things as the questions really required deep understanding.

Scored above mean 2 SD will guarantee you an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Just one mid-term and one final only.

reviews.author: Aysha
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are pretty straightforward and are easy to understand.
The topics range from plant hormones, plant cell structure e.g. pectin, lignin etc. Structure and life processes in plants; cellular structures; molecular and cellar mechanism; transport of water and nutrients; nutrition and soil; reproduction; photosynthesis; growth and development; biotechnology.

Though this seems like a lot, the content itself isn't overwhelming as compared to other courses, and is very interesting if you enjoy learning about plants.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I personally enjoy Li Ning's approach to teaching. He always highlights the important concept and "take-home message" after every lecture. He appropriately stresses the confusing part.. and uses good analogies to explain the concepts better. His slides either contain many pictures or too many words. Not all of em would be elaborated or discussed in the lecture, so best to attend his classes ( and for the record, he doesn't record his lectures)

Melody, on the other hand, is alright, her explanations and contents are usually present word for word in the ppt.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is reasonable. Most of the Classes managed to get a B
reviews.comment_workload: There are only Midterm and a final exam. The questions were pretty easy to moderate difficulty, given that you have revised well.
